Indian vegetarian food is not wimpy, pretentious  and overelaborately 
refined meat replacement like so much of Western veggie food. It is a real 
entity all to itself, and has thousands of years of history behind it. I so 
respect Bourdain for not being a vegetarian snob in this case. I now 
realize that much of his vegetarian dissing is based on a deep 
understanding of what the joy of eating, the soul of eating, is all about. 
Too bad animals have to be killed though. Signed, Vegetarian Guy..﻿

I am Canadian with an Indian background. I travelled to India for the very 
first time for three months. In all those months, I NEVER got sick. I just 
avoided eating raw foods for the first week and drank boiled water. After 
the first week, I ate everything! Even street food (which was the best). 
And I had no sickness. I love Indian food. I eat it all the time at home!﻿
comments.author: RainaGhai23

comments.text:
ok you westerners, here me out cuz i have a revelation for you. you need to 
know once and for all that, the first few times we south asians try your 
food it makes us crap too much too, it's just what you call "the body 
getting adjusted to the new diet in its system" whether the food is healthy 
or not. get it?!! cuz you have suddenly consumed something out the routine 
in terms of your regular diet for your body. so it's just what the human 
body does. secondly,...jeeezz indian food is relatively healthier!!! yess!! 
daaayyymmm! just like any other ethnic cuisine is. When it's comes to 
nutrition let me open your eyes that most indian food veg or non-veg is 
primarily organic veggies/poultry that we shop locally, less processed in 
relatively cheaper, and traditionally healthy ways(depending on how good of 
a host you have) and is surely nutritious & healthy enough or should I 
rather say certainly better in some cases than the 
highly-processed-additive containing-nutritionless synthetic western food, 
packaged, shelved, for god knows how long with preservatives, food that 
most probably has mold and yeast from poorly managed food processing units, 
long preserved packaged meats with tape worms and shit. :| Thirdly, when it 
comes to matter of "eating with hands", even the wealthiest of wealthy 
people in india have to eat certain food with hands, cuz that's just the 
proper etiquette and tradition, done hygienically by washing hands with 
soap before and after the meal(part of our dining routine in an indian 
setting), and whether it's a restaurant or at a friend/host's house our 
dining areas are equipped with a sink and some form of soap. So the next 
time when the subject of Indian food and health comes up in your 
conversations remember this comment. ok?!! :) thanks and come again! bye 
bye! :)﻿

comments.text:
Bro i would like to tell you few facts
1 The basis of Sikhism is non violence. And kindly read your epics, though 
you may say it is allowed but you should not forget vegetarianism is 
promoted in Sikhism.
2 There is a sect of Sikhism called "Naamdahri Sikh" believe me they will 
die of hunger rather then toughing meat. 
3 The ultimate message of Sikhism is Good Karma, so you ask any Sikh saint 
that is it good. They will never endorse meat eating.
4 Just because My sir name is Sharma, does not mean I am a practicing 
Hindu, I follow Naamdahri Sikhism which I took from my mother and maternal 
Grandparents who are  Sikhs.
5 And yes Hindus are 80 % so we may say that majority of them are veg
6 Bro as a Punjabi and a half Hindu (From Paternal side) and half Sikh 
(From my maternal side) I can say there is hardly any difference in 
lifestyle if you follow either religion. And the ultimate teaching and goal 
of both the religions is to improve Karma which you cannot do without 
abstaining form non veg.
7 Ask any Muslims about there forefathers. Not even a single would agree 
that they are descendants of Hindus, so until they change there stand I do 
not believe that they can be called as a part of Indian culture, because 
what I presume to be Indian culture is the people who originated here like 
Sikh, Jain, Hindus etc not from Saudi Arabia

of some reasons best known to them. And then he says Indians are heavy met 
eaters which includes civilians and trust me all the relatives of mine who 
are even in  Army are vegetarian, but they sometimes eat eggs so we may not 
call them pure vegetarian. 
And the idiosyncrasy of our culture is Vegetarianism, that is what makes 
our culture different from other. If due to western influence and some 
people who started eating non - veg due to there colonial inferiority 
complex, call meat eating our culture are mistaken.
